facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 25th January 1963 and has been in custody ever since as a result of a remand order passed by a court of competent jurisdiction which had taken cognizance of a criminal complaint against him.

District Magistrate, Burdwan, passed an order on 9th February 1963 directing that the petitioner should be detained, satisfied that it was necessary to prevent him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.
Detention order served on petitioner on 15th February 1963 in Burdwan Jail where he was kept.
Grounds of detention communicated to petitioner on the same day (15th February 1963) as required by s.7 of the Act.

Grounds indicate petitioner indulging in anti-social activities, threatening and assaulting people, disturbing public order in areas within Faridpur, Andal, Raniganj and Asansol police stations, with five instances cited.
State Government approved the detention order on 16th February 1963.
Case placed before Advisory Board which recommended continuance of detention.
State Government confirmed detention under s.11 of the Act on 23rd April 1963, served on petitioner in Burdwan Jail on 29th April 1963.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order of detention passed against and served on the petitioner Rameshwar Shaw while he was in jail custody is justified by section 3(1) of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

petitioner_arguments.text: Detention not justified by s.3(1) of the Act because petitioner was already in jail custody, so authority could not be satisfied that detention was necessary to prevent prejudicial acts as he had no freedom of action.
Order passed mala fide by District Magistrate.
Material facts in grounds of detention are imaginary and non-existent, some vague and irrelevant.
Some grounds relied on by detaining authority not disclosed to petitioner, making communication defective and affecting right to effective representation.
Petitioner denied opportunity to make representation to Advisory Board.

respondent_arguments.text: Open to authority to pass detention order against a person already in detention or jail.

court_reasoning.text: Strict construction required for preventive detention laws; safeguards liberally interpreted. Authority must be satisfied detention necessary to prevent prejudicial acts, which postulates freedom of action at time order brought into force.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Person already in jail custody cannot rationally be said to act prejudicially if not detained, as no freedom.

court_reasoning.text: Satisfaction under s.3(1)(a) is subjective and not justiciable, but order invalid if grounds irrelevant/vague or if served on person in custody without rational connection/proximity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Past conduct can be considered if proximate and rationally connected.

court_reasoning.text: Detention order can be passed against person in custody in some cases (e.g., short-term imprisonment, imminent release), but not here where petitioner in custody since 25 Jan 1963 and order served 15 Feb while locked up.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Basis absent: no postulate of prejudicial action without detention.

holdings.text: Detention order not justified by s.3(1)(a); District Magistrate acted outside powers.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya
precedents_cited.relevance: Satisfaction under s.3(1)(a) is subjective, not justiciable; reasonableness cannot be questioned.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ujagar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Past conduct/antecedent history can be taken into account for detention order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Past conduct/antecedent history can be taken into account for detention order.
No bar to fresh detention order on same grounds if prior defective on formal grounds; abstractly allows order while in detention but facts matter.
Assam HC view on s.3(1)(a) scope.
Assam HC view on s.3(1)(a) scope.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sahadat Ali v. State of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Valid where detention order passed in anticipation of release after prosecution abandoned.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Authority to detain if satisfied necessary to prevent prejudicial acts; grounds to be communicated; confirmation procedure. Detention invalid if served on person in custody without freedom postulate.

statutes_cited.relevance: Petition for enforcement of fundamental rights via habeas corpus.

statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in context of Sahadat Ali case for release report.

outcome.summary: Petition succeeds; order of detention passed by District Magistrate, Burdwan on 9th February 1963 set aside as not justified by s.3(1)(a) of Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

key_quotes.text: How can the authority come to the conclusion that a person who is in jail custody may act in a prejudicial manner unless he is detained?
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning why detention invalid when served in custody.

key_quotes.text: The scheme of the section postulates that if an order of detention is not passed against a person, he would be free and able to act in a prejudicial manner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains requirement of freedom of action for valid s.3(1)(a) satisfaction.

key_quotes.text: The detention of the petitioner in the circumstances of this case, is not justified by s.3(1)(a) and is outside its purview.
key_quotes.speaker: court
